{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}}
{{Use American English|date=May 2016}} The following is a '''list of pipeline accidents in the United States in 2015'''. It is one of several [[list of pipeline accidents in the United States|lists of U.S. pipeline accidents]]. See also [[list of natural gas and oil production accidents in the United States]]. {{expand list|date=April 2013}} __NOTOC__ <!--begin temporary compact toc--> <!-- something nicer-looking and more navigable should be done here; this is a temporary TOC to ease navigation --> <!-- | bgcolor=#dddddd align=center colspan=11 | See also – [[#References|References]] --> <!--end compact toc-->
== Incidents ==
This is not a complete list of all pipeline accidents. '''For natural gas alone''', the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA), a United States Department of Transportation agency, has collected data on more than 3,200 accidents deemed serious or significant since 1987.
A "significant incident" results in any of the following consequences: * fatality or injury requiring in-patient hospitalization * $50,000 or more in total costs, measured in 1984 dollars * liquid releases of five or more barrels (42 US gal/barrel) * releases resulting in an unintentional fire or explosion
PHMSA and the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) post incident data and results of investigations into accidents involving pipelines that carry a variety of products, including natural gas, oil, diesel fuel, gasoline, kerosene, jet fuel, carbon dioxide, and other substances. Occasionally pipelines are repurposed to carry different products.<ref>Data sets of PHMSA Pipeline Safety-Flagged Incidents for 1986-2001, 2002-2009, and 2010-2017 can be downloaded from the tab by that name on the PHMSA's Pipeline Incident Flagged Files page at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/data-and-statistics/pipeline/pipeline-incident-flagged-files, accessed 2018.01.10. PHMSA Corrective Action Orders are at https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/CAO_opid_0.html. PHMSA Pipeline Failure Investigation Reports are at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/safety-reports/pipeline-failure-investigation-reports. NTSB Pipeline Accident Reports are at https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/pipeline.aspx.</ref>
* On January 14, a fire broke out at an oil pipeline pump station, in [[Texas City, Texas]]. Texas City fire officials said that company officials reported that there had been issues with the pump station over the weekend. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.galvnews.com/news/free/article_699f91e8-9c22-11e4-97c3-63576ec5ef16.html|title=Pipeline fire shuts down FM 2004 in Texas City|first=T.J. AULDS and SHANNON|last=DAUGHTRY|publisher=}}</ref> * On January 14, during work to free a trapped inline inspection unit, a leak was discovered on the Evangeline Pipeline, near [[Cameron Parish, Louisiana]]. This pipeline had been given a Corrective Action Order in October 2014, due to a number of leaks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icis.com/resources/news/2015/01/14/9853014/us-evangeline-pipeline-shuts-down-after-leak-discovered/ |title=US Evangeline Pipeline shuts down after leak discovered |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702011745/http://www.icis.com/resources/news/2015/01/14/9853014/us-evangeline-pipeline-shuts-down-after-leak-discovered/ |archivedate=July 2, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.argusmedia.com/News/Article?id=976846 |title=News – Argus Media |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150516143633/http://www.argusmedia.com/News/Article?id=976846 |archivedate=May 16, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No.: 4-2014-5027H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420145027H/420145027H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_10202014_text.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170209132956/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420145027H/420145027H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_10202014_text.pdf |archivedate=February 9, 2017 }}</ref> * Also on January 14, a gas pipeline exploded near the [[Ross Barnett Reservoir]] in [[Brandon, Mississippi]], creating a sizable crater in the ground and burning 6 acres of vegetation before the fire was extinguished. No injuries were reported. The failure was due to a "hard spot" from manufacturing, that already had a repair sleeve on it. There are 788 sleeves on the Index 129 pipeline from Edna, Texas, to Sterlington, Louisiana; and, 726 sleeves on the Index 130 pipeline from Marchand Junction, Louisiana to Kosciusko, Mississippi. Both were built from pipe made in 1952.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wapt.com/news/central-mississippi/gas-line-explodes-burns-at-reservoir/30695664 |title=Gas line explodes, burns near reservoir |date=January 14, 2015 |publisher=[[WAPT]] News |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218044130/http://www.wapt.com/news/central-mississippi/gas-line-explodes-burns-at-reservoir/30695664 |archivedate=February 18, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clarionledger.com/story/news/2015/01/14/reservoir-explosion/21740325/|title=Reservoir gas pipeline fire extinguished|date=January 14, 2015|publisher=[[The Clarion-Ledger]]|accessdate=January 15, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CPF 2-2015-1001S |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/220151001S/220151001S_nopso_03272015_text.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211115940/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/220151001S/220151001S_nopso_03272015_text.pdf |archivedate=February 11, 2017 }}</ref> * On January 16, a transmission pipeline operated by [[Kinder Morgan]] subsidiary [[Southern Natural Gas]] had an equipment malfunction in [[Walthall County, Mississippi]]. The cause was cold weather; ice build-up caused a regulator to malfunction.<ref name="primis">Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration operator data, http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170603005753/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/ |date=June 3, 2017 }}, Retrieved April 1, 2016.</ref> * On January 17, oil from a broken pipeline seeped into the [[Yellowstone River]], and contaminated the water supply 10 miles south of Glendive, Montana. The release was from Bridger Pipeline LLC's 12-inch Poplar line, which can carry 42,000 barrels a day of crude from the [[Bakken Formation]] and runs from Canada south to Baker, Montana. Bridger Pipeline is a subsidiary of True Cos., a privately held Wyoming-based company. The company said in a statement that the pipeline was shut down within an hour of the leak. About 30,000 gallons of crude were spilled, with about 28,000 gallons of crude being lost.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sider |first1=Alison |title=Oil Spill Contaminates Montana Town's Water Supply, EPA Says |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/oil-spills-into-yellowstone-river-after-pipeline-leak-1421688172 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206043411/https://www.wsj.com/articles/oil-spills-into-yellowstone-river-after-pipeline-leak-1421688172 |archivedate=February 6, 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inforum.com/news/accidents/3661267-clean-water-likely-be-restored-glendive-thursday-after-oil-spill-along |title=Clean water likely to be restored to Glendive on Thursday after oil spill along Yellowstone |author=Tom Lutey |work=INFORUM |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128204750/http://www.inforum.com/news/accidents/3661267-clean-water-likely-be-restored-glendive-thursday-after-oil-spill-along |archivedate=January 28, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_31878.html?nocache=4750#_Incidents_tab_3 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications – Operator Information |author= |date= |work=dot.gov |accessdate=May 23, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308070842/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_31878.html?nocache=4750 |archivedate=March 8, 2016 }}</ref> * On January 21, a petroleum products pipeline in [[Honolulu, Hawaii]] ruptured, due to external corrosion, spilling about 42,000 gallons of petroleum product, of which about 22,000 gallons was lost.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_31056.html?nocache=5782#_Incidents_tab_3 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications – Operator Information |author= |date= |work=dot.gov |accessdate=May 23, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308054320/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_31056.html?nocache=5782 |archivedate=March 8, 2016 }}</ref> * On January 21, a crude oil pipeline pump station caught fire northwest of [[Texas City, Texas]]. Texas City fire officials said that company officials reported that there had been issues with the pump station over the weekend.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.galvestondailynews.com/free/article_699f91e8-9c22-11e4-97c3-63576ec5ef16.html|title=Pipeline fire shuts down FM 2004 in Texas City|work=The Galveston County Daily News|accessdate=January 18, 2016}}</ref> * On January 26, a 20-inch [[Enterprise Products]] ATEX pipeline carrying ethane exploded and burned, in [[Brooke County, West Virginia]]. Despite snow in the area, five acres of woodlands burned, and 1,283,000 gallons of ethane were consumed, or lost. The fireball melted siding on nearby homes and damaged power lines; it is believed that day’s snowy weather lessened the damage. Reports suspect a girth weld failure from ductile tensile overload, with the pipeline being less than two years old. Survey showed that the pipeline had slumped three feet since being built. A geotechnical survey conducted by Pennsylvania Soil and Rock determined that the failed pipe was installed across a transition area or “head wall” of an old underground mine and surface strip mine. There were no injuries.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_31618.html?nocache=6119#_Incidents_tab_5 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications - Operator Information |work=dot.gov |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161227132036/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_31618.html?nocache=6119 |archivedate=December 27, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theintelligencer.net/page/content.detail/id/623827/Fire-Burned-24-000-Barrels-of-Ethane.html?nav=515 |title=24,000 Ethane Barrels Burned |work=The Intelligencer |accessdate=September 16, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406055110/http://www.theintelligencer.net/page/content.detail/id/623827/Fire-Burned-24-000-Barrels-of-Ethane.html?nav=515 |archivedate=April 6, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://cms.phmsa.dot.gov/sites/phmsa.dot.gov/files/docs/inspections-and-investigations/17866/149469enterpriseproductsoperatingllcfir2015126reportandappendices.pdf |title=Report |website=cms.phmsa.dot.gov}}</ref> * On January 29, near [[Bowling Green, Missouri]], a rupture in a Rockies Express 42-inch-diameter natural gas pipeline blew a 20 by 20-foot crater and forced a six-hour evacuation of 50 families. The rupture occurred in a vacant field a few yards east of Pike County Road 43. Strong winds dissipated gas until a temporary cap was put in place.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pipeline Ruptures Near Pike 43 {{!}} The People's Tribune|url=http://thepeoplestribune.com/?p=25397|website=thepeoplestribune.com|accessdate=28 November 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150206054424/http://thepeoplestribune.com/?p=25397|archivedate=February 6, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> This explosion did $2,672,345 in property damage and was caused by a faulty weld; the pipe was manufactured in 2008.<ref>Operator Information, Pipeline & Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141030030518/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/ |date=October 30, 2014 }}</ref> * On February 10 in [[Hopkinton, Massachusetts]], low temperatures caused freezing rain to do "natural force damage" to a [[Kinder Morgan]] Tennessee Gas Pipeline, causing $55,150 worth of property damage.<ref name="primis"/> * On February 17, a suspected electrical arc made a hole in a [[Marathon Petroleum]] pipeline in [[Shively, Kentucky]], spilling about 6,700 gallons of jet fuel. More than 2,500 tons of soil were removed to clean up the area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wdrb.com/story/28752694/jet-fuel-remains-in-shively-soil-months-after-pipeline-spill |title=Jet fuel remains in Shively soil months after pipeline spill |author=Marcus Green |date=April 8, 2015 |work=wdrb.com |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115900/http://www.wdrb.com/story/28752694/jet-fuel-remains-in-shively-soil-months-after-pipeline-spill |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wdrb.com/story/30439304/more-than-2500-tons-of-soil-removed-from-shively-neighborhood-after-pipeline-spill |title=More than 2,500 tons of soil removed from Shively neighborhood a – WDRB 41 Louisville News |author=Marcus Green |date=November 4, 2015 |work=wdrb.com |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160111223557/http://www.wdrb.com/story/30439304/more-than-2500-tons-of-soil-removed-from-shively-neighborhood-after-pipeline-spill |archivedate=January 11, 2016 }}</ref> * On February 25, a 26-inch crude oil pipeline in [[Navarro County]] near the Town of [[Dawson, Texas]], failed, spill about 50 barrels of crude oil. Near the failure, investigation showed that the pipe had lost about 80% of its thickness due to external corrosion. This anomaly was not seen in a 2011 test of this pipeline.<ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 4-2015-5005H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420155005H/420155005H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_03122015_text.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220144109/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420155005H/420155005H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_03122015_text.pdf |archivedate=December 20, 2016 }}</ref> * On March 2, a [[Kinder Morgan]] Tennessee Gas Pipeline leaked due to equipment failure, causing $281,890 of property damage in Marshall, Mississippi. The pipe was manufactured in 1944.<ref name="primis"/> * On March 13 a pipeline Patrol pilot identified an oil sheen on a pond near [[Tehuacana Creek]], Texas which was then linked to a leaking 10 inch petroleum products pipeline. About 50 barrels of diesel fuel were spilled.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wacotrib.com/news/environment/cleanup-begins-on-diesel-pipeline-spill-near-tehuacana-creek/article_20e9cb1d-75ad-5b17-90a5-374c35f6876a.html|title=Cleanup begins on diesel pipeline spill near Tehuacana Creek|work=WacoTrib.com|accessdate=January 18, 2016}}</ref> * On March 20, a pipe owned by [[Kinder Morgan]] subsidiary [[Southern Natural Gas]] failed in [[Rolling Fork, Mississippi]]; the pipe was manufactured in 1930.<ref name="primis"/> * On March 23, another [[Southern Natural Gas]] pipeline failed due to a cracked weld at [[Augusta, Georgia]], causing $311,785 in property damage.<ref name="primis"/> * On April 9, 2 [[Williams Companies]] pipelines broke within hours of each other in [[Marshall County, West Virginia]]. A 4-inch condensate pipeline broke at 8 pm local time, spilling about 132 barrels of condensate into a creek. Around 10:50 pm local time, a 12-inch gas pipeline ruptured. There was no fire or injuries. Heavy rains were said to be the cause of the failures.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theintelligencer.net/page/content.detail/id/630275/-Heavy-Rains--Cited-In-Marshall----.html |title=‘Heavy Rains’ Cited In Marshall Pipeline Failure |publisher=The Intelligencer |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150417105218/http://www.theintelligencer.net/page/content.detail/id/630275/-Heavy-Rains--Cited-In-Marshall----.html |archivedate=April 17, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theintelligencer.net/page/content.detail/id/630514/DEP--132-Barrels-Spilled-Into-Marshall-County-Creek.html?nav=515 |title=DEP: 132 Barrels Spilled Into Marshall County Creek |work=The Intelligencer |accessdate=September 16, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304113043/http://www.theintelligencer.net/page/content.detail/id/630514/DEP--132-Barrels-Spilled-Into-Marshall-County-Creek.html?nav=515 |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }}</ref> * On April 13, a [[Kinder Morgan]] / [[Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America]] pipeline exploded and burned near [[Borger, Texas]]. One home was evacuated, but there were no injuries. The explosion, caused by equipment failure due to environmental cracking, caused $455,000 in property damage.<ref>{{cite web|title=Natural gas pipeline fire near Borger extinguished |url=http://www.newschannel10.com/story/28788786/natural-gas-pipeline-fire-near-borger-extinguished |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160408102808/http://www.newschannel10.com/story/28788786/natural-gas-pipeline-fire-near-borger-extinguished |archivedate=April 8, 2016 }}</ref> A 60-foot section and a 30-foot section of pipe were ejected and landed about 60 feet and 100 feet away from the failure site, respectively. Metallurgical analysis revealed the cause of the leak was stress corrosion cracking. The pipe was manufactured in 1967.<ref>PHMSA Corrective Action Orders 4-2003-1008H, 4-2012-1011H and CPF No. 4-2015-1006H, http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420151006H/420151006H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_04172015_text.pdf, accessed 1/12/2016.</ref> * On April 17, a 12-inch natural gas pipeline near [[Fresno, California]] operated by [[Pacific Gas and Electric Company]] was ruptured by a backhoe. The resulting explosion killed 1 person and injured 12 others.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pipeline explosion at Fresno shooting range caused by front loader, state report says |url=http://www.fresnobee.com/news/local/article26618077.html |accessdate=August 21, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150802204616/http://www.fresnobee.com/news/local/article26618077.html |archivedate=August 2, 2015 }}</ref> * On May 15, [[Kinder Morgan]]'s [[Tennessee Gas Pipeline]] leaked in Powell County, [[Kentucky]] causing $23,400 in property damage.<ref name="primis"/> * On May 19, a [[Plains All American Pipeline]] oil pipeline ruptured near [[Refugio State Beach]], also near [[Goleta, California]], spilling about 124,000 gallons of crude oil. It is referred to as the [[Refugio Oil Spill]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/05/20/us/california-oil-spill/ |title=California oil spill: Up to 105,000 gallons lost – CNN.com |author1=Paul Vercammen |author2=Pat St. Claire |date=May 20, 2015 |work=CNN |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160129203930/http://edition.cnn.com/2015/05/20/us/california-oil-spill/ |archivedate=January 29, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Failure Investigation Report], (PDF) ''Plains Pipeline, L.P., Line 901, Crude Oil Release, May 19, 2015, Santa Barbara County, California; May 2016''|url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/pv_obj_cache/pv_obj_id_8B90E29F8ABBC9A581DEB7D209A0B0D901737301/filename/PHMSA_Failure_Investigation_Report_Plains_Pipeline_LP_Line_901_Public.pd}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * On May 31, a 24-inch diameter [[Texas Eastern]] natural gas pipeline under the flooding [[Arkansas River]] ruptured in [[Little Rock, Arkansas]], damaging a tugboat which "sustained damage on the port side, the smokestack and main deck." The pipeline exploded with enough force to raise geysers of water in the river and also threw cement chunks onto the tugboat‘s deck. The pipeline is owned by Houston-based [[Spectra Energy]].<ref>Benjamin Hardy, “Natural gas pipeline ruptures east of I-30 bridge, closing two miles of Arkansas River,” ''Arkansas Times'', June 2, 2015, https://www.arktimes.com/ArkansasBlog/archives/2015/06/02/natural-gas-pipeline-ruptures-east-of-i-30-bridge-closing-two-miles-of-arkansas-river; and “Arkansas River pipeline blowout occurred on Sunday morning, cause still unknown,” ''Arkansas Times'', June 2, 2015, https://www.arktimes.com/ArkansasBlog/archives/2015/06/03/arkansas-river-pipeline-blowout-occurred-on-sunday-morning-cause-still-unknown, accessed 2018.01.10.</ref> Analysis concluded that high water flow in the river eroded the cover over the pipeline and scoured away the soil support under the pipeline. Once the pipeline was exposed as a free span, rushing water caused vertical oscillation of the pipe, resulting in metal fatigue, cracking the pipe adjacent to a girth weld. The pipe was manufactured in 1952.<ref name="primis"/> * On June 9 in Moorehouse Parish, Louisiana, [[Kinder Morgan]]'s [[Tennessee Gas Pipeline]] equipment failed due to environmental cracking, and leaked, causing $73,395 in property damage. The pipe was manufactured in 1948.<ref name="primis"/> * On June 9, a 24-inch natural gas pipeline ruptured in [[Lycoming County, Pennsylvania]]. About 130 individuals were evacuated from their homes. No injuries or damage reported. There was no fire. The cause was [[stress corrosion cracking]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Williams natgas pipeline in Pennsylvania ruptures; no injuries |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/06/11/us-natgas-williams-transco-idUSKBN0OR1R720150611 |newspaper=Reuters |date=June 11, 2015 |accessdate=August 21, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924220446/https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/06/11/us-natgas-williams-transco-idUSKBN0OR1R720150611 |archivedate=September 24, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Failure Investigation Report – Williams Partners L.P./Transco 24” Leidy Line B Failure, Unityville, PA 6/9/2015 |url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles//PHMSA/PipelineFailureReports/150663_Transcontinental_Unityville_PA_June_9_2015.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170210021346/http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/PipelineFailureReports/150663_Transcontinental_Unityville_PA_June_9_2015.pdf# |archivedate=February 10, 2017 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The pipe was installed in 1963. When it failed, it was owned by Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Company.<ref name="primis"/> * On June 10, [[Kinder Morgan]]'s [[El Paso Natural Gas]] control/relief equipment failed and leaked in Gray County, Texas. Technicians believed debris or trash may have caused the valve to malfunction.<ref name="primis"/> * On June 13, an [[Energy Transfer Partners]] 42-inch gas gathering pipeline exploded and burned near [[Cuero, Texas]]. Seven homes were evacuated, but there were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.victoriaadvocate.com/news/2015/jun/17/pipeline-rupture-released-thousands-of-pounds-of-g/ |title=Pipeline rupture released thousands of pounds of gas vapors |work=victoriaadvocate.com |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115900/https://www.victoriaadvocate.com/news/2015/jun/17/pipeline-rupture-released-thousands-of-pounds-of-g/ |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref> The heat from the flames melted electric lines, cutting off power to 130 homes. Sixteen people were evacuated from homes near the explosion, which caused $500,000 in damage. Energy Transfer Company reported to the [[Texas Commission on Environmental Quality]] that as much as 165,732 pounds of volatile organic compounds burned. The [[Railroad Commission of Texas]], in its Pipeline Safety Evaluation, and Inspection Package number 111385, published November 2, 2015, concluded that material failure, as a result of bending stress overload that caused a weld to fail, led to the rupture, explosion, and fire. The pipeline was constructed and installed in 2012.<ref>Sara Sneath, "Pipeline operator won't be penalized for explosion," ''Victoria Advocate'', December 6, 2015, https://www.victoriaadvocate.com/news/2015/dec/06/pipeline-operator-wont-be-penalized-for-explosion/ A copy of the investigative report is posted on this website.</ref> * On June 15, [[Kinder Morgan]]'s Natural Gas Pipeline Co. of America equipment failed adjacent to a weld seam for unknown causes, with $260,555 of property damage in [[Marshall, Texas]] (that area's third documented Kinder Morgan leak). The pipe was manufactured in 1967.<ref name="primis"/> * On June 18, in Victoria Texas, [[Kinder Morgan]]'s [[Tennessee Gas Pipeline]] pipe failed due to external corrosion and caused $159,346 in property damage. The pipe was manufactured in 1944.<ref name="primis"/> * On June 22, a truck driver was killed when his rig veered off a highway and broke above ground facilities for a propylene pipeline in [[Houston, Texas]]. The highway was closed for several hours while the gas dissipated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/houston/article/Truck-collision-with-pipeline-backs-up-traffic-on-6342233.php |title=Texas 225 eastbound reopens after a truck collision with feeder road pipeline shut it down |work=[[Houston Chronicle]] |date=June 22, 2015 |accessdate=December 8, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151231211851/http://www.chron.com/houston/article/Truck-collision-with-pipeline-backs-up-traffic-on-6342233.php |archivedate=December 31, 2015 }}</ref> * Four workers were hurt on June 25, when a 4-inch gas pipeline exploded at a gas pipeline facility, near [[White Deer, Texas]]. 2 of the workers were critically injured. The cause of the explosion was not immediately known.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/4-Injured-in-White-Deer-Gas-Line-Explosion-310324841.html |title=4 Injured in White Deer Gas Line Explosion |work=NBC 5 Dallas-Fort Worth |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115900/http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/4-Injured-in-White-Deer-Gas-Line-Explosion-310324841.html |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref> * On July 10, a fitting on a 20-inch [[Plains All American Pipeline]] crude oil pipeline broke, spilling 4200 gallons of crude oil near [[Grantfork, Illinois]]. Much of the crude reached a nearby creek. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bnd.com/news/local/community/highland-news-leader/article27426022.html |title=Highland resident files suit against oil company responsible for spill |work=bnd |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115859/http://www.bnd.com/news/local/community/highland-news-leader/article27426022.html |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref> * On July 15, two workers were hurt by an explosion, when a bulldozer hit a 4-inch gas pipeline, at an [[EQT]] gas compressor station in [[Worthington, Pennsylvania]]. One of the workers later on died from the injuries. While the contractor did use the 811 One call system, the pipeline hit was not a participant of 811. Later this incident was a factor in restricting 811 exemptions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wtae.com/news/worker-injured-in-pipeline-accident/34188004 |title=2 workers hurt in explosion when backhoe strikes gas line |author=Sheldon Ingram |date=July 29, 2015 |work=WTAE |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115859/http://www.wtae.com/news/worker-injured-in-pipeline-accident/34188004 |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2016/02/19/worker-dies-in-pipeline-accident-puc-steps-up-calls-for-reform/|title=Worker dies in pipeline accident, PUC steps up calls for reform - StateImpact Pennsylvania|publisher=}}</ref> * On August 3, a [[Kinder Morgan]] [[Tennessee Gas Pipeline]] 16-inch diameter pipe exploded; the blowout created a 70-foot by 30-ft crater 350 feet from a house and did $191,498 in property damage. Investigation found a longitudinal split in the pipe about 55 feet long along an [[Electric resistance welding|ERW]] seam, but the failure was from [[stress corrosion cracking]]. The pipe was manufactured in 1947.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sheriff's Office: Natural gas pipeline 'explosion' forced 150 Falfurrias families from their homes |url=http://www.valleycentral.com/news/story.aspx?id=1239109 |website=Valley Central |accessdate=August 21, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150814074847/http://www.valleycentral.com/news/story.aspx?id=1239109 |archivedate=August 14, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 4-2015-1009H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420151009H/420151009H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_08062015.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221002010/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420151009H/420151009H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_08062015.pdf |archivedate=December 21, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles//PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/Pipeline/Failure%20Reports/TGP_151027_Falfurrias_TX_2015_08_03_Final_Redacted.pdf |title=Failure Investigation Report—Tennessee Gas Pipeline Company, LLC, |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170218052247/http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles//PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/Pipeline/Failure%20Reports/TGP_151027_Falfurrias_TX_2015_08_03_Final_Redacted.pdf# |archivedate=February 18, 2017 |access-date=October 5, 2018 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * On August 7, a natural gas liquids pipeline in [[Weld County, Colorado]] burned after being struck by a third party.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fire on Williams pipeline |url=http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/1408027/fire-on-williams-pipeline |website=www.upstreamonline.com |accessdate=August 21, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150810054745/http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/1408027/fire-on-williams-pipeline |archivedate=August 10, 2015 }}</ref> * 0n August 13, crew working for [[Colonial Pipeline]] damaged one of Colonial's lines in [[Kannapolis, North Carolina]], spilling about 6,000 gallons of petroleum product. About 1,000 gallons of product was lost.<ref name="dot5">{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_2552.html?nocache=7343#_Incidents_tab_3 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications – Operator Information |author= |date= |work=dot.gov |accessdate=May 23, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307113746/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_2552.html?nocache=7343 |archivedate=March 7, 2016 }}</ref> * On August 13, a natural gas pipeline in [[Cypress, Texas]] ruptured and leaked while a contract crew worked in the area. The pipeline was owned by Gulfsouth Pipeline. There were no injuries or immediate damage; residents were evacuated.<ref>{{cite web|title=All-clear given to Cypress residents evacuated after gas leak |url=http://www.click2houston.com/news/fd-hazmat-responding-to-gas-leak-in-northwest-harris-county/34706166 |accessdate=September 6, 2015 |last=KPRC |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906075718/http://www.click2houston.com/news/fd-hazmat-responding-to-gas-leak-in-northwest-harris-county/34706166 |archivedate=September 6, 2015 }}</ref> * On August 26, two maintenance divers were injured while working on a pipeline owned by Boardwalk/Gulf South Pipeline Co. 25 miles offshore of [[Louisiana]] when the pipeline ruptured, and the gas ignited.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://maritime-executive.com/article/two-injured-in-louisiana-pipeline-fire |title=Two Injured in Louisiana Pipeline Fire |work=The Maritime Executive |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115900/http://maritime-executive.com/article/two-injured-in-louisiana-pipeline-fire |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref> *On September 5, 2015, Great Lakes Gas Transmission Company had an explosion at a compressor station in [[Kittson County, Minnesota]], about a mile south of the Canadian border. The cause was mechanical failure caused by stress corrosion cracking. The pipe was installed in 1972.<ref name="primis"/> * On September 16, a [[Shell Oil Company]] crude oil pipeline leaked near [[Tracy, California]], spilling about 37,800 gallons of crude. An in line inspection report of that pipeline two weeks before had detected no anomalies.<ref name="climatechangenews.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.climatechangenews.com/2018/08/07/oil-pipeline-inspection-industry-going-wrong-surveys-fail-prevent-spills/|title=Oil pipeline inspection industry 'going wrong' as surveys fail to prevent spills|date=August 7, 2018|publisher=}}</ref> * On September 21, a [[Colonial Pipeline]] 32-inch main line leaked in [[Centreville, Virginia]], spilling about 4,000 gallons of gasoline and forcing several nearby businesses to close.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wtop.com/fairfax-county/2015/09/gas-leak-forces-fairfax-co-business-closures/slide/1/ |title=Gas leak forces Fairfax Co. business closures |date=September 24, 2015 |work=WTOP |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115900/http://wtop.com/fairfax-county/2015/09/gas-leak-forces-fairfax-co-business-closures/slide/1/ |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/PAB1701.pdf |title=National Transportation Safety Board Pipeline Accident Brief|website=ntsb.gov |publisher=NTSB}}</ref> * On October 8, natural gas ignited and exploded at a [[Williams Companies]] pipeline facility in [[Gibson, Louisiana]]. Four employees were killed and one injured. Cost of the accident was $7,545,044. The cause of the explosion was from procedure not being followed during welding work.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wdsu.com/news/local-news/new-orleans/explosion-reported-at-natural-gas-pipeline-in-gibson/35726080 |title=Police: 3 dead, 2 in serious condition after Gibson plant explosion |author=Clint Durrett |date=May 15, 2012 |work=WDSU |accessdate=May 23, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160526180907/http://www.wdsu.com/news/local-news/new-orleans/explosion-reported-at-natural-gas-pipeline-in-gibson/35726080 |archivedate=May 26, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_19570.html?nocache=8429#_Incidents_tab_4 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications – Operator Information |author= |date= |work=dot.gov |accessdate=May 23, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307161646/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_19570.html?nocache=8429 |archivedate=March 7, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=CPF 4-2016-1008 |url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/Pipeline/420161008_NOPV_PCP_PCO_07292016.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161231184226/http://phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/Pipeline/420161008_NOPV_PCP_PCO_07292016.pdf# |archivedate=December 31, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * On November 3, 2015, a leak occurred due to a crack in a girth weld on a Texas Eastern Transmission 24-inch diameter pipeline near [[Onalaska, Texas]]. The pipe was manufactured in 1954.<ref name="primis"/> * On November 13, at [[Bakersfield, California]], a heavy equipment operator doing agricultural work struck a 30-inch-diameter [[PG&E]] natural gas transmission line, causing a release of gas. The gas ignited and in the resulting explosion one person died and three others were sent to the hospital with second- and third-degree burns. A nearby home and barn were damaged by the fire.<ref name="primis"/><ref>Steven Mayer, J.W. Burch IV, James Burger and John Cox, "One dead and three injured in PG&E natural gas line explosion southwest of Bakersfield," November 13, 2015, http://www.bakersfield.com/news/one-dead-and-three-injured-in-pg-e-natural-gas/article_98f3c442-fef3-541a-a2d6-fc77f6e22b00.html, accessed 2018.01.11.</ref> * On November 15, work was being performed on a flow control valve, on a [[Sunoco]] 10 inch crude oil pipeline, in [[Wortham, Texas]], when the valve failed, injuring 5 workers, and spilling some crude oil. It was later determined that the valve was under 400 psi of nitrogen pressure when it was being worked on.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/pipeline/phmsa-failure-investigation-results-in-notice-of-probable-violation-and-proposed-civil-penalty-for-sunoco-pipeline |title=PHMSA – Briefing Room |first=Department of Transportation's Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety |last=Administration |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161104141746/http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/pipeline/phmsa-failure-investigation-results-in-notice-of-probable-violation-and-proposed-civil-penalty-for-sunoco-pipeline# |archivedate=November 4, 2016 |access-date=October 5, 2018 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> *On November 21, 2015, Paiute Pipeline personnel were running an inline inspection tool through the 8-inch-diameter Carson lateral pipeline. The leading eye of the tool struck the inside of a long radius 45-degree elbow, puncturing the pipe and resulting in a rupture. Public and private property damage included six vehicles and a landscape retaining wall as a result of the blowing dirt and rocks.<ref name="primis"/> * On November 30, about 11,000 gallons of gasoline, butane and propane leaked from a pipeline, in eastern [[Summit County, Utah]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865642766/11000-gallons-of-gasoline-butane-and-propane-leak-from-pipeline-in-Summit-County.html?pg=all |title=11,000 gallons of gasoline, butane and propane leak from pipeline in Summit County |author= |date=November 30, 2015 |work=DeseretNews.com |accessdate=May 23, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306212804/http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865642766/11000-gallons-of-gasoline-butane-and-propane-leak-from-pipeline-in-Summit-County.html?pg=all |archivedate=March 6, 2016 }}</ref> *On December 1, personnel from Enterprise Crude Pipeline, LLC ([[Enterprise Products]]), discovered a spill at their West Cushing Tank Farm in [[Cushing, Oklahoma]]. Approximately 42,000 gallons of crude oil were released within the terminal. A tank line had failed from internal corrosion.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles//PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/Pipeline/Failure%20Reports/Enterprise_Crude_Pipeline_LLC_Cushing_West_Terminal_2015_12_01_Redacted.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-05-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170430084914/https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles//PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/Pipeline/Failure%20Reports/Enterprise_Crude_Pipeline_LLC_Cushing_West_Terminal_2015_12_01_Redacted.pdf# |archivedate=April 30, 2017 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * On December 8, a contractor drilled into an {{convert|8|inch|mm|adj=mid| buried oil line}}, that transports oil from a holding station in [[Ventura, California|Ventura]], to a Wilmington refinery, near [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]], while setting new poles for [[Southern California Edison]] along [[California State Route 118|State Route 118]] near [[Somis, California|Somis]] that spilled about {{convert|7980|USgal|oilbbl|abbr=off|sp=us}}.<ref>{{cite news|title=Highway 118 commuters beware: Somis oil spill cleanup will take days |date=December 9, 2015 |work=[[Ventura County Star]] |first1=Cindy |last1=Von Quednow |first2=Cheri |last2=Carlson |url=http://www.vcstar.com/topstories/Oil-spill-reported-in-Somis-360929811.html |last-author-amp=yes |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151210221037/http://www.vcstar.com/topstories/Oil-spill-reported-in-Somis-360929811.html |archivedate=December 10, 2015 }}</ref>

Flaherty]] | music = [[Virgil Thomson]] | cinematography = [[Richard Leacock]] | editing = [[Helen van Dongen]] | distributor = [[Lopert Films]] | released = {{Film date|1948|09|28|U.S.}} | runtime = 78 minutes | country = United States | language = English
French }} '''''Louisiana Story''''' ([[1948 in film|1948]]) is a 78-minute black-and-white American film. Although the events and characters depicted are fictional and the film was commissioned by the [[Standard Oil Company]] to promote its drilling ventures in the Louisiana bayoux, it is often misidentified as a [[documentary film]], when in fact, it is a [[docufiction]]. The script was written by [[Frances H. Flaherty]] and [[Robert J. Flaherty]], directed by Robert J. Flaherty. ==Plot== The film deals with the adventures of a young [[Cajun]] boy and his pet [[raccoon]], who live a somewhat idyllic existence playing in the [[bayou]]s of [[Louisiana]]. A sub-plot involves his elderly father's allowing an oil company to drill for oil in the inlet that runs behind their house. A completely assembled miniature [[Oil platform|oil rig]] on a slender barge is towed into the inlet from connecting narrow waterways. Although there is a moment of crisis when the rig strikes a gas pocket, most of this is dealt with swiftly and off-camera, and the barge, rig, and friendly drillers depart expeditiously, leaving behind a phenomenally clean environment and a wealthy Cajun family. Conflict and action for the plot is provided by the presence of a giant [[alligator]] in the area, which is believed to have eaten the pet [[raccoon]] and which is hunted in revenge. There is no individual or organized resistance to the incursion of the oil seekers, even after the (brief, offscreen) disaster, who are unequivocally portrayed as friendly, progressive humanitarians. The boy, named in the film as Alexander Napoleon Ulysses Le Tour but in the credits just identified as "the boy", was played by [[Joseph Boudreaux]]. The film was photographed by [[Richard Leacock]] and edited by [[Helen van Dongen]], who were also the associate producers. Original release was through independent film distributor [[Lopert Films]]. ==Production== The film was shot on location in the Louisiana bayou country,{{cite book|title=LIFE|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hk4EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA137|date=2 May 1949|publisher=Time Inc|page=137|issn=0024-3019}} using local residents for actors. However, none of the members of the Cajun family (boy, father and mother) were actually related, and the film does not deal with Cajun culture, the reality of the hard lives of the Cajun people, or with the mechanics of drilling for oil. The story itself is completely fictional. In 1952, it was reissued by an [[exploitation film]] outfit with a new title, ''Cajun'', on the bottom-half of a double-bill with another film called ''Watusi''.{{cite book|last1=Calder-Marshall|first1=Arthur|last2=Rotha|first2=Paul|last3=Wright|first3=Basil|title=The Innocent Eye: The Life of Robert J. Flaherty|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1M5ZAAAAMAAJ|year=1963|publisher=Harcourt, Brace & World|page=224}} ==Reception and awards== The film was nominated for an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] for [[Academy Award for Writing Original Screenplay|Best Writing, Motion Picture Story]] in 1948.{{cite book|last=Gevinson|first=Alan|title=Within Our Gates: Ethnicity in American Feature Films, 1911-1960|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bsoUXGZSxZcC&pg=PA614|year=1997|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-20964-0|page=614}} In 1949, [[Virgil Thomson]] won the [[Pulitzer Prize for Music]] for his score to the film (which is based on a famous field tape of indigenous Cajun musicians and was performed by the Philadelphia Symphony). Through 2016, this has remained the only Pulitzer Prize awarded for a film score.{{cite book |last=McLane |first=Barbara A. |title=A New History of Documentary Film: Second Edition |page=68 |date=2012 |publisher=Bloomsbury Academic |isbn=978-1441124579 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rt0Wwjs4zyYC&pg=PA68}} [[Pulitzer Prize for Music |Wikipedia list of Pulitzer Prizes for Music]] In 1994, ''Louisiana Story'' was selected for preservation in the United States [[National Film Registry]] by the [[Library of Congress]] as being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant". The movie was also in the top 10 of the first British Film Institute's Sight and Sound poll in 1952. The film is recognized by [[American Film Institute]] in these lists: * 2005: [[AFI's 100 Years of Film Scores]] – Nominated{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/scores250.pdf |title= AFI's 100 Years of Film Scores Nominees |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2016-08-06}} == See also == * [[Docufiction]] * [[List of docufiction films]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0040550}} *{{rotten-tomatoes|louisiana_story|Louisiana Story}} *{{Internet Archive film|LouisianaStory}} *[http://southernspaces.org/2010/revisiting-flahertys-louisiana-story Patricia A. Suchy and James V. Catano, "Revisiting Flaherty's ''Louisiana Story''", ''Southern Spaces'' (27 April 2010)] {{PulitzerPrize Music 1943–1950}} {{Robert J. Flaherty}} {{Sight and Sound Poll}} [[Category:1948 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:United States National Film Registry films]] [[Category:Films directed by Robert Flaherty]] [[Category:Films set in Louisiana]] [[Category:Sponsored films]] [[Category:American docufiction films]] [[Category:Works about petroleum]] [[Category:Pulitzer Prize for Music-winning works]]

A flavor of the [[k·p perturbation theory|'''k·p''' perturbation theory]] used for calculating the structure of multiple, degenerate electronic bands in bulk and [[quantum well]] [[semiconductors]]. The method is a generalization of the single band '''k[[k·p perturbation theory|·]]<nowiki/>p''' theory.
In this model the influence of all other bands is taken into account by using [[Per-Olov Löwdin|Löwdin]]'s perturbation method.<ref name=Chuang1> {{cite book |author=S.L. Chuang |title=Physics of Optoelectronic Devices |year= 1995 |edition=First |publisher=Wiley |pages=124–190 |location=New York |isbn=978-0-471-10939-6 |url=http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/31134252}} </ref>
== Background ==
All bands can be subdivided into two classes:
* '''Class A''': six valence bands (heavy hole, light hole, split off band and their spin counterparts) and two conduction bands. * '''Class B''': all other bands.
The method concentrates on the bands in ''Class A'', and takes into account ''Class B'' bands perturbatively.
We can write the perturbed solution <math>\phi^{}_{}</math> as a linear combination of the unperturbed eigenstates <math>\phi^{(0)}_{i}</math>:
:<math>\phi = \sum^{A,B}_{n} a_{n} \phi^{(0)}_{i}</math>
Assuming the unperturbed eigenstates are orthonormalized, the eigenequation are:
:<math>(E-H_{mm})a_m = \sum^{A}_{n\neq m}H_{mn}a_{n} + \sum^{B}_{\alpha \neq m}H_{m\alpha}a_{\alpha}</math>,
where
:<math>H_{mn} = \int \phi^{(0)\dagger}_{m} H \phi^{(0)}_{n}d^3 \mathbf{r} = E^{(0)}_{n}\delta_{mn}+H^{'}_{mn}</math>.
From this expression we can write:
:<math>a_{m} = \sum^{A}_{n\neq m} \frac{H_{mn}}{E-H_{mm}} a_{n} + \sum^{B}_{\alpha\neq m} \frac{H_{m\alpha}}{E-H_{mm}} a_{\alpha} </math>,
where the first sum on the right-hand side is over the states in class A only, while the second sum is over the states on class B. Since we are interested in the coefficients <math>a_{m}</math> for ''m'' in class A, we may eliminate those in class B by an iteration procedure to obtain:
:<math>a_{m} = \sum^{A}_{n\neq m} \frac{U^{A}_{mn} - H_{mn}}{E-H_{mm}} a_{n} </math>,
:<math>U^{A}_{mn} = H_{mn} + \sum^{B}_{\alpha\neq m} \frac{H_{m\alpha}H_{\alpha n}}{E-H_{\alpha\alpha}} + \sum_{\alpha,\beta\neq m,n;\alpha\neq\beta} \frac{H_{m \alpha} H_{\alpha\beta}H_{\beta n} }{(E-H_{\alpha\alpha})(E-H_{\beta\beta})} + \ldots </math>
Equivalently, for <math> a_{n} </math> (<math> n \in A </math>):
:<math>a_{n} = \sum^{A}_{n} (U^{A}_{mn} - E\delta_{mn})a_{n} = 0, m \in A </math>
and
:<math> a_{\gamma} = \sum^{A}_{n} \frac{ U^{A}_{\gamma n} - H_{\gamma n}\delta_{\gamma n}}{E-H_{\gamma\gamma}} a_{n} = 0, \gamma \in B </math>.
When the coefficients <math> a_{n} </math> belonging to Class A are determined so are <math> a_{\gamma} </math>.
== Schrödinger equation and basis functions ==
The [[Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics)|Hamiltonian]] including the spin-orbit interaction can be written as:
:<math> H = H_0 + \frac{\hbar}{4m_{0}^{2}c^{2}}\bar{\sigma}\cdot\nabla V \times \mathbf{p} </math>,
where <math> \bar{\sigma} </math> is the [[Pauli spin matrix]] vector. Substituting into the [[Schrödinger equation]] we obtain
:<math> H u_{n\mathbf{k}}(\mathbf{r}) = \left( H_0 + \frac{\hbar}{m_{0}}\mathbf{k}\cdot\mathbf{\Pi} + \frac{\hbar^2 k^2}{4m_{0}^{2}c^{2}} \nabla V \times \mathbf{p} \cdot \bar{\sigma} \right) u_{n\mathbf{k}}(\mathbf{r}) = E_{n}(\mathbf{k}) u_{n\mathbf{k}}(\mathbf{r}) </math>,
where
:<math> \mathbf{\Pi} = \mathbf{p} + \frac{\hbar}{4m_{0}^{2}c^{2}}\bar{\sigma} \times \nabla V </math>
and the perturbation Hamiltonian can be defined as
:<math> H' = \frac{\hbar}{m_0}\mathbf{k}\cdot\mathbf{\Pi}. </math>
The unperturbed Hamiltonian refers to the band-edge spin-orbit system (for ''k''=0). At the band edge, conduction band [[Bloch waves]] exhibit s-like symmetry, while valence band states are p-like (3-fold degenerate without spin). Let us denote these states as <math> |S \rangle </math>, and <math> |X \rangle </math>, <math> |Y \rangle </math> and <math> |Z \rangle </math> respectively. These Bloch functions can be pictured as periodic repetition of atomic orbitals, repeated at intervals corresponding to the lattice spacing. The Bloch function can be expanded in the following manner:
:<math> u_{n \mathbf{k}} (\mathbf{r}) = \sum^{A}_{j'} a_{j'}(\mathbf{k}) u_{j'0}(\mathbf{r}) + \sum^{B}_{\gamma} a_{\gamma}(\mathbf{k}) u_{\gamma 0}(\mathbf{r}) </math>,
where ''j' '' is in Class A and <math> \gamma </math> is in Class B. The basis functions can be chosen to be
:<math> u_{10}(\mathbf{r}) = u_{el}(\mathbf{r}) = \left | S\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2} \right \rangle = \left|S\uparrow\right\rangle </math> :<math> u_{20}(\mathbf{r}) = u_{SO}(\mathbf{r}) = \left | \frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2} \right \rangle = \frac{1}{\sqrt 3} |(X+iY)\downarrow\rangle + \frac{1}{\sqrt 3} |Z\uparrow\rangle </math> :<math> u_{30}(\mathbf{r}) = u_{lh}(\mathbf{r}) = \left | \frac{3}{2},\frac{1}{2} \right \rangle = -\frac{1}{\sqrt 6} |(X+iY)\downarrow\rangle + \sqrt{\frac{2}{3}} |Z\uparrow\rangle </math> :<math> u_{40}(\mathbf{r}) = u_{hh}(\mathbf{r}) = \left | \frac{3}{2},\frac{3}{2} \right \rangle = -\frac{1}{\sqrt 2}|(X+iY)\uparrow\rangle </math> :<math> u_{50}(\mathbf{r}) = \bar{u}_{el}(\mathbf{r}) = \left | S\frac{1}{2},-\frac{1}{2} \right \rangle = -|S\downarrow\rangle </math> :<math> u_{60}(\mathbf{r}) = \bar{u}_{SO}(\mathbf{r}) = \left | \frac{1}{2},-\frac{1}{2} \right \rangle = \frac{1}{\sqrt 3} |(X-iY)\uparrow\rangle - \frac{1}{\sqrt 3} |Z\downarrow\rangle </math> :<math> u_{70}(\mathbf{r}) = \bar{u}_{lh}(\mathbf{r}) = \left | \frac{3}{2},-\frac{1}{2} \right \rangle = \frac{1}{\sqrt 6} |(X-iY)\uparrow\rangle + \sqrt{\frac{2}{3}} |Z\downarrow\rangle </math> :<math> u_{80}(\mathbf{r}) = \bar{u}_{hh}(\mathbf{r}) = \left | \frac{3}{2},-\frac{3}{2} \right \rangle = -\frac{1}{\sqrt 2}|(X-iY)\downarrow\rangle </math>.
Using Löwdin's method, only the following eigenvalue problem needs to be solved
:<math> \sum^{A}_{j'} (U^{A}_{jj'}-E\delta_{jj'})a_{j'}(\mathbf{k}) = 0, </math>
where
:<math> U^{A}_{jj'} = H_{jj'} + \sum^{B}_{\gamma \neq j,j'} \frac{H_{j\gamma}H_{\gamma j'}}{E_0-E_{\gamma}} = H_{jj'} + \sum^{B}_{\gamma \neq j,j'} \frac{H^{'}_{j\gamma}H^{'}_{\gamma j'}}{E_0-E_{\gamma}} </math>,
:<math> H^{'}_{j\gamma} = \left \langle u_{j0} \right | \frac{\hbar}{m_0} \mathbf{k} \cdot \left ( \mathbf{p} + \frac{\hbar}{4 m_0 c^2} \bar{\sigma} \times \nabla V \right ) \left | u_{\gamma 0} \right \rangle \approx \sum_{\alpha} \frac{\hbar k_{\alpha}}{m_0}p^{\alpha}_{j \gamma}. </math>
The second term of '''<math> \Pi </math>''' can be neglected compared to the similar term with '''p''' instead of '''k'''. Similarly to the single band case, we can write for <math> U^{A}_{jj'} </math>
:<math> D_{jj'} \equiv U^{A}_{jj'} = E_{j}(0)\delta_{jj'} + \sum_{\alpha\beta} D^{\alpha\beta}_{jj'}k_{\alpha}k_{\beta}, </math>
:<math> D^{\alpha\beta}_{jj'} = \frac{\hbar^2}{2 m_0} \left [ \delta_{jj'}\delta_{\alpha\beta} + \sum^{B}_{\gamma} \frac{ p^{\alpha}_{j\gamma}p^{\beta}_{\gamma j'} + p^{\beta}_{j\gamma}p^{\alpha}_{\gamma j'} }{ m_0 (E_0-E_{\gamma}) } \right ]. </math>
We now define the following parameters
:<math> A_0 = \frac{\hbar^2}{2 m_0} + \frac{\hbar^2}{m_0^2} \sum^{B}_{\gamma} \frac{ p^{x}_{x\gamma}p^{x}_{\gamma x} }{ E_0-E_{\gamma} }, </math>
:<math> B_0 = \frac{\hbar^2}{2 m_0} + \frac{\hbar^2}{m_0^2} \sum^{B}_{\gamma} \frac{ p^{y}_{x\gamma}p^{y}_{\gamma x} }{ E_0-E_{\gamma} }, </math>
:<math> C_0 = \frac{\hbar^2}{m_0^2} \sum^{B}_{\gamma} \frac{ p^{x}_{x\gamma}p^{y}_{\gamma y} + p^{y}_{x\gamma}p^{x}_{\gamma y} }{ E_0-E_{\gamma} }, </math>
and the band structure parameters (or the '''[[Luttinger parameter]]s''') can be defined to be
:<math> \gamma_1 = - \frac{1}{3} \frac{2 m_0}{\hbar^2} (A_0 + 2B_0), </math>
:<math> \gamma_2 = - \frac{1}{6} \frac{2 m_0}{\hbar^2} (A_0 - B_0), </math>
:<math> \gamma_3 = - \frac{1}{6} \frac{2 m_0}{\hbar^2} C_0, </math>
These parameters are very closely related to the effective masses of the holes in various valence bands. <math> \gamma_1 </math> and <math> \gamma_2 </math> describe the coupling of the <math> |X \rangle </math>, <math> |Y \rangle </math> and <math> |Z \rangle </math> states to the other states. The third parameter <math> \gamma_3 </math> relates to the anisotropy of the energy band structure around the <math> \Gamma </math> point when <math> \gamma_2 \neq \gamma_3 </math>.
== Explicit Hamiltonian matrix ==
The Luttinger-Kohn Hamiltonian <math> \mathbf{D_{jj'}} </math> can be written explicitly as a 8X8 matrix (taking into account 8 bands - 2 conduction, 2 heavy-holes, 2 light-holes and 2 split-off)
:<math> \mathbf{H} = \left( \begin{array}{cccccccc}
E_{el} & P_z & \sqrt{2}P_z & -\sqrt{3}P_{+} & 0 & \sqrt{2}P_{-} & P_{-} & 0 \\ P_z^{\dagger} & P+\Delta & \sqrt{2}Q^{\dagger} & -S^{\dagger}/\sqrt{2} & -\sqrt{2}P_{+}^{\dagger} & 0 & -\sqrt{3/2}S & -\sqrt{2}R \\ E_{el} & P_z & \sqrt{2}P_z & -\sqrt{3}P_{+} & 0 & \sqrt{2}P_{-} & P_{-} & 0 \\ E_{el} & P_z & \sqrt{2}P_z & -\sqrt{3}P_{+} & 0 & \sqrt{2}P_{-} & P_{-} & 0 \\ E_{el} & P_z & \sqrt{2}P_z & -\sqrt{3}P_{+} & 0 & \sqrt{2}P_{-} & P_{-} & 0 \\ E_{el} & P_z & \sqrt{2}P_z & -\sqrt{3}P_{+} & 0 & \sqrt{2}P_{-} & P_{-} & 0 \\ E_{el} & P_z & \sqrt{2}P_z & -\sqrt{3}P_{+} & 0 & \sqrt{2}P_{-} & P_{-} & 0 \\ E_{el} & P_z & \sqrt{2}P_z & -\sqrt{3}P_{+} & 0 & \sqrt{2}P_{-} & P_{-} & 0 \\
\end{array} \right) </math>
== Summary ==

Spinel structural group | formula = Mg(Fe3+)2O4 | strunz = 4.BB.05 | dana = | system = [[Cubic crystal system|Cubic]] | class = Hexoctahedral (m{{overline|3}}m)
[[H-M symbol]]: (4/m {{overline|3}} 2/m) | symmetry = ''F''d{{overline|3}}m | unit cell = a = 8.3866 Å; Z = 8 | color = Black to brownish black | habit = As octahedral crystals, massive granular | twinning = Twin plane {{mset|111}}, contact twins | cleavage = On {{mset|111}} | fracture = Uneven | tenacity = Brittle | mohs = 6 - 6.5 | luster = Metallic, semimetallic, dull | streak = Dark red | diaphaneity = Opaque, transparent in thin fragments | gravity = 4.55 – 4.65 measured | density = | polish = | opticalprop = Isotropic | refractive = n = 2.38 | birefringence = | pleochroism = | 2V = | dispersion = | extinction = | length fast/slow = | fluorescence = | absorption = | melt = | fusibility = | diagnostic = | solubility = | impurities = | alteration = | other = Magnetic | prop1 = | prop1text = | references = [http://rruff.geo.arizona.edu/doclib/hom/magnesioferrite.pdf Handbook of Mineralogy][http://www.mindat.org/min-2501.html Magnesioferrite on Mindat.org][http://webmineral.com/data/Magnesioferrite.shtml Magnesioferrite on Webmineral] }} '''Magnesioferrite''' is a magnesium iron [[oxide]] mineral, a member of the [[magnetite]] series of [[spinel group|spinel]]s. Magnesioferrite crystallizes as black metallic [[octahedral]] crystals. It is named after its chemical composition of [[magnesium]] and ferric [[iron]]. The density is 4.6 - 4.7 (average = 4.65), and the diaphaniety is opaque. Occurs as well-formed fine sized crystals or massive and granular. Its hardness is 6-6.5. It has a metallic luster and a dark red streak. ==Occurrence== It occurs in [[fumarole]]s, as a result of [[combustion metamorphism]] and [[Coal fire|coal seam fires]], in glass spherules related to [[meteorite impact]]s, and as accessory phase in [[kimberlite]]s and [[carbonatite]]s. It has been reported from [[Vesuvius]] and [[Stromboli]], [[Italy]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Commons category|Magnesioferrite}} [[Category:Iron minerals]] [[Category:Magnesium minerals]] [[Category:Spinel group]] [[Category:Cubic minerals]] {{oxide-mineral-stub}}

[[Image:March8196912UTCstorm.gif|thumb|A [[surface weather analysis]] of the storm when near its peak intensity on the morning of March 8, 1969]]
The '''March 1969 nor'easter''' was an [[extratropical cyclone]] that moved into the Gulf of Mexico on March 5, moving through southern Georgia, then deepened as it moved along the lower Eastern Seaboard, before swinging wide of New England and Atlantic Canada. Heavy snows fell across eastern Maryland, southern Delaware, and [[Martha's Vineyard]] in Massachusetts. It was a strong system, with [[maximum sustained wind]]s of {{convert|80|kn|km/h|abbr=on}} a central pressure close to {{convert|950|hPa|inHg|abbr=on}} while south of Atlantic Canada. The system then moved into the far northern Atlantic Ocean while splitting into two [[low pressure area]]s on March 10.
==Evolution== Late on March 5, a frontal wave moved offshore Galveston, Texas. The system moved along the Gulf coast on March 6.<ref name="first">{{cite journal|journal=Mariners Weather Log|page=160|date=July 1969|volume=13|number=4|editor=Richard W. Schwerdt|publisher=Department of Commerce|title=Letter to the Editor}}</ref> Gale-force winds were confined to behind its prefrontal [[squall line]] on March 6. The cyclone moved along the Florida-Georgia border with a central pressure down to {{convert|995.0|hPa|inHg}}. The low tracked up the Eastern Seaboard from the late on the 6th through the morning of the 7th while strengthening quickly, with its central pressure falling to {{convert|969.0|hPa|inHg}}, then with storm-force winds offshore [[Cape Charles, Virginia]]. The cyclone tracked offshore New England. By the morning of the 8th, the cyclone's center pressure had fallen to {{convert|950.0|hPa|inHg|abbr=on}} while the system developed maximum sustained winds of {{convert|80|kn|km/h}} south of Newfoundland.<ref name="first"/> During the day, the cyclone absorbed a previously strong cyclone to its north near [[Anticosti Island]]. The system slowly weakened while moving slowly northeast offshore eastern Newfoundland on the 9th and 10th, losing hurricane-force winds on the 9th. The system split into two distinct low pressure centers on 10th as it approached southern Greenland.<ref name="second">{{cite journal|journal=Mariners Weather Log|pages=181–182|date=July 1969|volume=13|number=4|editor=Richard W. Schwerdt|publisher=Department of Commerce|title=Rough Log, North Atlantic Weather March–May 1969}}</ref>
==Impact== The cyclone's pre-frontal squall line moved into western Florida between 4:30 and 6:00 p.m. on March 6. Winds gusted to between {{convert|45|mph|km/h}} and {{convert|60|mph|km/h}} across Sarasota and Levy counties. Tides rose to between {{convert|3|ft|m}} and {{convert|4|ft|m}} above normal. Damage caused was between $50,000 and $500,000. A heavy wet snow fell across the Eastern Shore of Maryland and the southern half of Delaware from late on March 6 into March 7, up to a depth of {{convert|7|in|cm}} in Maryland and {{convert|12.5|in|cm}} in [[Lewes, Delaware]]. At Martha's Vineyard, heavy snow and winds up to {{convert|50|mph|km/h}} created snow drifts exceeding {{convert|3|ft|m}} in height.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Storm Data|volume=11|number=3|date=March 1969|pages=20–21|publisher=Environmental Data Service|title=Delaware, Florida, Maryland, and Massachusetts}}</ref>

[[File:Con Ed steam stack 7th Ave and 20th Street from north.jpg|thumb|250px|Steam vapor being vented through a typical [[Consolidated Edison|Con Edison]] orange and white [[smokestack|stack]] on [[Seventh Avenue (Manhattan)|Seventh Avenue]] at [[22nd Street (Manhattan)|West 22nd Street]]. Steam vapor such as this can be caused by a leak in Con Ed's steam system – which heats and cools buildings in [[Manhattan]] up to [[89th Street (Manhattan)|East 89th]] and [[96th Street (Manhattan)|West 96th Street]] – or by cooler water contacting the outside of a steam pipe.<ref name=conedsteam>[http://www.coned.com/steam/kc_faqs.asp "Steam operations FAQ"] on the Con Edison website</ref>]]
The '''New York City steam systems''' include [[Con Edison|Con Edison’s]] Steam Operations, and other smaller steam systems that provide steam to [[New York University]] and [[Columbia University]]. Many individual buildings in New York have their own steam systems.
==Con Edison’s Steam Operations==
Con Edison’s Steam Operations is a [[district heating]] system which takes [[steam]] produced by steam generating stations and carries it under the streets of [[Manhattan]] to heat and cool high rise buildings and businesses. Some New York businesses and facilities also use the steam for cleaning and disinfection.
The '''New York Steam Company''' began providing service in [[lower Manhattan]] on March 3, 1882.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.coned.com/history/steam.asp |title=A Brief History of Con Edison |publisher=Con Edison |accessdate=2014-05-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060312062632/http://www.coned.com/history/steam.asp |archivedate=2006-03-12 |df= }}</ref> Today, [[Consolidated Edison]] operates the largest commercial [[District heating|steam system]] in the world. It's bigger than the next nine put together.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/10/nyregion/miles-of-steam-pipes-snake-beneath-new-york.html|title=Miles of Steam Pipes Snake Beneath New York|first=Greg|last=Moyer|date=9 October 2014|publisher=|accessdate=20 July 2017|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> The organization within Con Edison that is responsible for the system's operation is known as '''Steam Operations''', providing steam service to over 1,700 customers and serving commercial and residential establishments in Manhattan from [[Battery Park]] to [[96th Street (Manhattan)|96th Street]] uptown on the West side and 89th Street on the East side of Manhattan.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.coned.com/-/media/files/coned/documents/for-commercial-industries/steam/steamenergybrochure.pdf |title=Steam Energy |publisher=Con Edison |accessdate=July 5, 2017}}</ref> Roughly {{convert|24|e9lb|tonnes}} of steam flow through the system every year.<ref name=conedsteam />
==Uses== Steam provides heat and cooling to many buildings in New York. The steam system provides humidity to art museums, steam cleaning for restaurants to clean dishes, and other uses.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/10/nyregion/miles-of-steam-pipes-snake-beneath-new-york.html|title=Miles of Steam Pipes Snake Beneath New York|first=Greg|last=Moyer|date=9 October 2014|publisher=|accessdate=20 July 2017|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref>
==Environmental effects== Approximately 30% of the ConEd steam system’s installed capacity and 50% of the annual steam generated comes from cogeneration.<ref>[http://www.coned.com/publicissues/PDF/Steam%20Long%20Range%20Plan%20Final%20December%202010.pdf "Con Edison Steam Long Range Plan 2010-2030"], p. 69</ref> [[Cogeneration]] and Heat Recovery Steam Generation (HRSG) significantly increases the fuel efficiency of cogenerated electricity and thereby reduces the [[air pollution|emission of pollutants]], such as [[NOx]], [[sulfur dioxide]], [[carbon dioxide]], and particulate matter, and reduces the city's [[carbon footprint]]. Con Edison is promoting the use of steam for cooling in the summer months, something that can be accomplished with the installation of [[absorption chiller]]s.<ref>[http://www.coned.com/steam/PDF/May2_Seminar/HYBRID%20Cooling.pdf Benefits and Case Studies of Hybrid Cooling Using Steam] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071008014254/http://www.coned.com/steam/PDF/May2_Seminar/HYBRID%20Cooling.pdf |date=2007-10-08 }}, Consolidated Edison</ref> Such [[trigeneration]] systems reduce peak electrical loads and save construction costs associated with expanding electrical infrastructure.
Clouds of condensation can sometimes be seen rising from [[manhole]]s in Manhattan through orange and white "chimneys". This can be caused by external water being boiled by contact with the steam pipes or by leaks in the steam system itself.<ref name=conedsteam />
At least 12 steam pipe explosions have occurred in New York City since 1987.<ref>Belson, Ken and DePalma, Anthony. [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/19/nyregion/19steam.html "Asbestos and Aging Pipes Remain Buried Hazards"], ''[[The New York Times]]'' (July 19, 2007).</ref> The most recent incident was the 2018 Steam Pipe explosion which occurred in the Flatiron District and forced the evacuation of 49 buildings.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wral.com/high-pressure-steam-leak-in-manhattan-no-injuries-reported/17707888/|title=28 buildings evacuated in NYC steam pipe explosion :: WRAL.com|last=WRAL|work=WRAL.com|access-date=2018-07-19|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cnbc.com/2018/07/19/steam-pipe-explosion-in-manhattans-flatiron-spurs-evacuation.html|title=Asbestos found at steam pipe explosion in Manhattan's Flatiron District|last=Brassil|first=Gillian|date=2018-07-19|work=CNBC|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref> The explosion released concrete, asphalt, "[[asbestos]]-containing material" and mud into the air. The asbestos cleared out of the air to safe-level.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www1.nyc.gov/assets/doh/downloads/pdf/em/steam-pipe-explosion.pdf|title=Steam Pipe Explosive Event: Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)|last=|first=|date=19 July 2018|website=NYC.gov|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=20 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www1.nyc.gov/office-of-the-mayor/news/364-18/transcript-mayor-de-blasio-delivers-on-manhattan-steam-pipe-explosion/#/0|title=Mayor de Blasio Delivers Update On Manhattan Steam Pipe Explosion|date=July 19, 2018|work=The official website of the City of New York|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref> A previous incident was the [[2007 New York City steam explosion]], and another on June 28, 1996, at a plant on East 75th Street.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.fdnewyork.com/con_ed.asp |first=Frank |last=Raffa |title=Con-Ed Blows Off Some Steam |publisher=FDNewYork.com |accessdate=February 20, 2014}}</ref>
==Plants== {{kml}} [[File:Con Edison E74 jeh.JPG|thumb|250px|[[East 74th Street]] plant]] [[Image:W58th St IRT power jeh.JPG|thumb|250px|[[IRT Powerhouse|West 59th Street]] plant]]
*[[East 74th Street]] Station (at FDR Drive) {{coord|40.7668749|-73.9508952}} *60th Street Station (at York Ave.) {{coord|40.7598303|-73.9589127}} *59th Street Station (at 11th Ave.) ([[IRT Powerhouse]]) {{coord|40.7689531|-73.991624}} *East River Station (14th St. and FDR) ([[cogeneration]]) {{coord|40.7277782|-73.9732059}} *BNYCP Plant ([[Brooklyn Navy Yard]] Cogeneration Partners) ([[cogeneration]]) {{coord|40.699314|-73.976086}} *Ravenswood "A" House Steam Station (Queens) {{coord|40.7561804|-73.9503086}}<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/10/nyregion/miles-of-steam-pipes-snake-beneath-new-york.html|title=Miles of Steam Pipes Snake Beneath New York|first=Greg|last=Moyer|date=9 October 2014|publisher=|accessdate=20 July 2017|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref>
==Systems for individual buildings==
In New York City, many individual buildings use either a hot water or a steam system for heating, and will have a boiler in the basement. A boiler is an enclosed vessel or tank that heats water using oil or gas.
A steam boiler will usually keep the heat at 180 degrees F, then when the thermostat indicates that heat is needed it will increase the temperature to above the boiling point, 212 degrees F. This will send steam, which is lighter than air, to rise through pipes into the building’s radiators. Many thermostats measures outdoor air temperature instead of room temperature to determine — this is less efficient
There are differences between hot water heat and steam heat. Steam heat is noisier, but it delivers heat quicker. Steam systems can produce more uneven heat, and the radiators are generally larger.
The noise known as a “steam-hammer” sounds like someone hammering on a pipe. It is caused when water condenses and is trapped in a horizontal section of pipe so it cannot drain back to the boiler. Then when the system is next turned on, this water is hurled by the steam into the pipe fittings, creating the loud bang.<ref>[https://www.edf.org/sites/default/files/10087_EDF_BottomBarrel_ch2.pdf] Environmental Defense Fund webpage</ref>

[[Image:Proton Exchange Fuel Cell Diagram.svg|thumb|Scheme of a phosphoric acid fuel cell]] '''Phosphoric acid fuel cells''' ('''PAFC''') are a type of [[fuel cell]] that uses liquid [[phosphoric acid]] as an [[electrolyte]]. They were the first fuel cells to be commercialized. Developed in the mid-1960s and field-tested since the 1970s, they have improved significantly in stability, performance, and cost. Such characteristics have made the PAFC a good candidate for early stationary applications.<ref>http://energy.gov/eere/fuelcells/types-fuel-cells#phosphoric.</ref>
==Design== Electrolyte is highly concentrated or pure liquid phosphoric acid (H<sub>3</sub>PO<sub>4</sub>) saturated in a [[silicon carbide]] matrix (SiC). Operating range is about 150 to 210 °C. The [[electrode]]s are made of [[carbon paper]] coated with a finely dispersed [[platinum]] [[catalyst]].
==Electrode reactions==
Anode reaction: 2H<sub>2</sub>(g) → 4H<sup>+</sup> + 4e‾
Cathode reaction: O<sub>2</sub>(g) + 4H<sup>+</sup> + 4e‾ → 2H<sub>2</sub>O
Overall cell reaction: 2 H<sub>2</sub> + O<sub>2</sub> → 2H<sub>2</sub>O
==Advantages and disadvantages== At an operating range of 150 to 200 °C, the expelled water can be converted to steam for air and water heating ([[Cogeneration|combined heat and power]]). This potentially allows [[thermodynamic efficiency|efficiency]] increases of up to 70%.<ref>[http://energycenter.org/index.php/technical-assistance/renewables/fuel-cells Fuel Cells<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101123204231/http://energycenter.org/index.php/technical-assistance/renewables/fuel-cells |date=November 23, 2010 }}</ref> PAFCs are [[carbon dioxide | CO<sub>2</sub>]]-tolerant and even can tolerate a [[carbon monoxide | CO]] concentration of about 1.5%, which broadens the choice of fuels they can use. If gasoline is used, the sulfur must be removed.<ref name="FCorg">[http://www.fuelcells.org/basics/types.html Fuel Cells 2000 : Fuel Cell Basics : Types<!-- Bot generated title -->].</ref> At lower temperatures phosphoric acid is a poor ionic conductor, and CO poisoning of the platinum electro-catalyst in the anode becomes severe.<ref name="FuelcellHandbook">[http://www.netl.doe.gov/technologies/coalpower/fuelcells/seca/pubs/fchandbook7.pdf] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101123023857/http://www.netl.doe.gov/technologies/coalpower/fuelcells/seca/pubs/fchandbook7.pdf |date=November 23, 2010 }}</ref> However, they are much less sensitive to CO than PEFCs and AFCs.
Disadvantages include rather low power density and aggressive electrolyte.{{clarify|date=January 2012}}
==Applications== [[File:PureCell System 400 CEP.jpg|thumb|PureCell System 400 CEP]] PAFC have been used for stationary power generators with output in the 100 kW to 400 kW range and are also finding application in large vehicles such as buses.<ref name="FCToday">[http://www.fuelcelltoday.com/about-fuel-cells/technologies/pafc Fuel Cell Today - Home Page<!-- Bot generated title -->].</ref>
Major manufacturers of PAFC technology include Doosan Fuel Cell America Inc.<ref>http://www.doosanfuelcell.com/en/main.do.</ref> (formerly [[ClearEdge Power]] & UTC Power<ref>[http://www.clearedgepower.com/news/clearedge-power-completes-acquisition-utc-power ClearEdge Power – Media Room<!-- Bot generated title -->].</ref>) and [[Fuji Electric]].
India's [[DRDO]] has developed PAFC for [[air-independent propulsion]] for integration into their [[Kalvari-class submarine]]s.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/indianbuilt-scorpene-to-carry-critical-drdo-system/article6558305.ece| title=Indian-built Scorpene to carry critical DRDO system | publisher=The Hindu | date=3 Nov 2014 | accessdate=2015-10-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article1016372.ece | title=DRDO working on system to cut submarine vulnerability | date= 30 December 2010 | first=S. | last=Anandan | newspaper=The Hindu}}</ref>

{{For|the World War II Pipeline Under The Ocean project|Operation Pluto}} '''Project Pluto''' was a [[United States]] government program to develop [[Nuclear-powered aircraft|nuclear-powered]] [[ramjet]] engines for use in [[cruise missile]]s. Two experimental engines were tested at the [[United States Department of Energy]] [[Nevada Test Site]] ('''NTS''') in 1961 and 1964.<ref>[http://www.nv.doe.gov/library/factsheets/DOENV_763.pdf DOE] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303003018/http://www.nv.doe.gov/library/factsheets/DOENV_763.pdf |date=2012-03-03 }}''</ref>
==History== On January 1, 1957, the [[U.S. Air Force]] and the [[United States Atomic Energy Commission|U.S. Atomic Energy Commission]] selected the [[Lawrence Radiation Laboratory]] (the predecessor of the [[Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory]]'s, LLNL) to study the feasibility of applying heat from [[nuclear reactor]]s to [[ramjet]] engines. This research became known as "'''Project Pluto'''". The work was directed by Dr. [[Ted Merkle]], leader of the laboratory's R-Division.
[[Image:Tory-IIC nuclear ramjet at Jackass Flats in 1955.jpg|right|thumb|The "Tory-IIC" prototype]] Originally carried out at [[Livermore, California]], the work was moved to new facilities constructed for $1.2 million on {{convert|8|sqmi}} of [[Jackass Flats]] at the NTS, known as Site 401. The complex consisted of {{convert|6|mi|0}} of roads, critical-assembly building, control building, assembly and shop buildings, and utilities. Also required for the construction was {{convert|25|mi}} of oil well casing, which was necessary to store the approximately {{convert|1000000|lb}} of pressurized air used to simulate ramjet flight conditions for Pluto.
The principle behind the nuclear ramjet was relatively simple: motion of the vehicle pushed air in through the front of the vehicle (ram effect), a nuclear reactor heated the air, and then the hot air expanded at high speed out through a nozzle at the back, providing thrust.
The notion of using a nuclear reactor to heat the air was fundamentally new. Unlike commercial reactors, which are surrounded by concrete, the Pluto reactor had to be small and compact enough to fly, but durable enough to survive a {{convert|7000|mi|adj=on}} trip to a potential target. The nuclear engine could, in principle, operate for months, so a Pluto cruise missile could be left airborne for a prolonged time before being directed to carry out its attack.
The success of this project would depend upon a series of technological advances in [[metallurgy]] and [[materials science]]. [[Pneumatic motor]]s necessary to control the reactor in flight had to operate while red-hot and in the presence of intense [[ionizing radiation|radiation]]. The need to maintain [[supersonic]] speed at low altitude and in all kinds of weather meant that the reactor, code-named "Tory", had to survive high temperatures and conditions that would melt the metals used in most [[jet engine|jet]] and [[rocket engine]]s. [[Ceramic]] fuel elements would have to be used; the contract to manufacture the 500,000 pencil-sized elements was given to the [[Coors Porcelain Company]].
The proposed use for nuclear-powered ramjets would be to power a [[cruise missile]], called SLAM, for [[Supersonic Low Altitude Missile]]. In order to reach ramjet speed, it would be launched from the ground by a cluster of conventional rocket boosters. Once it reached cruising altitude and was far away from populated areas, the nuclear reactor would be made critical. Since nuclear power gave it almost unlimited range, the missile could cruise in circles over the ocean until ordered "down to the deck" for its supersonic dash to targets in the Soviet Union. The SLAM, as proposed, would carry a payload of many nuclear weapons to be dropped on multiple targets, making the cruise missile into an unmanned bomber. After delivering all its warheads, the missile could then spend weeks flying over populated areas at low altitudes, causing tremendous ground damage with its shock wave and fallout. When it finally lost enough power to fly, and crash-landed, the engine would have a good chance of spewing deadly radiation for months to come.
On May 14, 1961, the world's first nuclear ramjet engine, "Tory-IIA", mounted on a railroad car, roared to life for a few seconds. Three years later, "Tory-IIC" was run for five minutes at full power. Despite these and other successful tests, [[the Pentagon]], sponsor of the "Pluto project", had second thoughts. The weapon was considered "too provocative",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vought.org/special/html/sslam4.html |title=Muscle in Mothballs |accessdate=2014-07-21}}</ref> and it was believed that it would compel the Soviets to construct a similar device, against which there was no known defense. [[Intercontinental ballistic missile]] technology had proven to be more easily developed than previously thought, reducing the need for such highly capable cruise missiles. On July 1, 1964, seven years and six months after it was started, "Project Pluto" was canceled.
